Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learned some basic R coding, but definitely not enough statistics.
I learned basic R coding as well as introductory statistical analysis and inference.
not much
Basic R coding, basic data analysis and inference.
I learned about different aspects of description and inference in statistics, as well as how to use R programming.
We learned the basic techniques of description and inference. The class focused on developing proficiency in R.
Basic statistics and statistics techniques
A very basic understanding of statistics and R coding.
Not much to be honest. If you took AP STATS in high school, this class covers literally only the first month. We're talking variable types, plots, stats, hypothesis testing, and confidence intervals.
I learned lot about statistics and r.
Some basic statistic analysis plus some new ability to code
I learned how to analyze, describe, and infer given a data set
Hhs
I had learned a more traditional approach to statistics in the past, so this was my first experience with using R code. It was a relatively easy introduction to programming.
Basic understanding of how to use R software and some knowledge of basic statistics.
RStudio, basic stats
I learned basic knowledge of stats and how to use r programming.
Learned about some basic descriptive data analysis and some pretty introductory inferential data analysis. Also, learning R was a huge plus.
None.
basics of R coding, main strategies for data analysis, how to program, read, and interpret various kinds of plots
I learned basic skills in R, but thats about it.
Well, I learned some basics about statistics.
How to code basic functions using R
introductory statistics concepts and using R code

The most important skill I gained through this course was experience with using the program R. I have never coded or done any sort of programming before, so this was a good introduction to the  topic and definitely did not go too fast in teaching the material pertaining to programming.
Basic statistics knowledge and some R coding skills
To be honest I did not feel like I learned anything relevant from this course. It felt like a ton of busy work.
Lectures went by super fast and if you don't have a firm understanding of the material, you will get lost.

Dr. Brinda is clearly brilliant but seems to be struggling with how to teach the course material. When leading us through concepts, he would only really go through what was already written in the textbook (which he wrote and was not much more helpful) and never really took us through practice problems until right before our third quiz. He did as much as he could to ensure that we would all do well in the class, especially after it became clear that most of us did not feel at all comfortable with the course material.
weird approach, wack lectures, boring

We didn't learn anything. The class moved slowly to the point of being condescending, and too much time was spent learning R instead of statistics. The professor would go through examples without explaining any of his work, telling us not to worry about it. For someone with an interest in math, this is not the class.

This course was honestly a bit of a mess, but not necessarily in a bad way. There was no syllabus, so we had very few assignments at the beginning of the semester and a lot at the end. This was not ideal in theory, but the assignments got easier towards the end despite there being more of them, so it wasn't a huge problem. The material was very understandable and explained well at the beginning of the semester, but towards the end I found myself relying heavily on the textbook because I felt that I was not learning anything in class.

Strengths: R and the ULAs 

weaknesses: class lacked direction, depth, and organization.
Didnt super enjoy the structure of the course. Felt like we were rushing at the end there
The course did not have much work, but it is unclear as to exactly what it was trying to cover.
I found that the course moves at too slow of a pace for the level of the academic material. However, Professor Brinda is a caring teaching who obviously enjoys the material he teaches

Need's more structure, and better explanations. The online textbook wasn't finished, and lots of valuable information wasn't available. The textbook is much too involved for the level of this course. If the explanations--specifically within the book--were explained more clearly, this course would be much more enjoyable.

Strengths: very easy
Weakness: the prof seemed confused at times and was not very good at explaining things
Professor Brinda is very knowledgeable and helpful but not the best teacher.
There is a lot of support for learning the material
Hi

When you go to office hours, it is easy to get help on assignments and clarity on class materials. In class, it can be hard to follow R code and I feel there needs to be a more interactive element to question understanding as the professor teaches code in class, because it is easy to check out of the lectures. Sometimes the questions on the problem sets weren't easy to answer solely based on what material was covered in lecture; it required a more complex understanding. The professor made clear what would be covered on the quizzes and the tests, which was helpful.
This course felt like it wasnt paced correctlywe ended up rushing at the end and struggled to get through a lot of material. At times it felt more like rote memorization than learning the content.
The syllabus was unclear and the material, especially coding, was very rushed.
The course felt a bit scattered and not very focused.

I wish there were powerpoint presentations that we could follow. Lectures were pretty hard to follow because a lot of the information was written out by hand on the blackboard and it was easy to miss. The textbook made understanding a little easier, but I would have appreciated some lecture slides to review after class. 
Otherwise, the grade distribution (homeworks, quizzes, exams, projects) were all pretty straightforward. I appreciated the pretty even grade distribution between all different parts of the class and that it was easy to improve your grade.
The course was very disorganized and I did not know what we were supposed to even be doing/studying.

The material was interesting but often poorly explained. Code was often provided for trickier parts of homework assignments, but it was hard to truly gain an understanding of the course material. The final project was also not explained particularly well; most of us were confused as to what the professor was looking for in the project until the very end of the class.

I appreciate that the course taught us useful skills in R, but I dont think the course did a good job at actually teaching statistics. We spent far too much time on R and then were forced to rush through the actual mathematics of statistics.
It was not set up very well. Assignments weren't too bad, but the criteria for grading and what you actually had to know was always unclear.
No guidelines as to how the course would be run.
this class was straightforward, but it could have been more facilitated towards student learning

I think that the integration of the content and its applications through programming was a great idea, but I think at one point we just stopped using R, but I had wanted to keep learning and practicing more to get better at it and gain new skills.
The textbook for this course is very thorough and useful, but I think we could have focused more on R coding.

Anyone who took this course should seriously consider retaking it with another professor. The main takeaway from the course was the different graphs you would use in different scenarios. We barely learned any math that one would use in statistics. It was just one chapter that wasn't even covered on the final. Also, the textbook used has very poor explanations. I am surprised that Yale does not preapprove textbooks because this was Prof. William's first couple of years teaching at Yale and he is already using his own textbook.
We could actually focus on learning R and understanding the language instead of just learning cursory phrases.
Yes. You learn the necessary information to analyze datasets, but in a nonstressful setting.

Humanities students trying to find a QR: go somewhere else! I beg you. Just take a math course, even CS50. Seriously, don't do this to yourself. I was so lost, frustrated, and uninspired throughout the duration of the class. You have been warned.

I would not recommend this course. If you are looking for an introductory statistics course, take 101-106. This class did not teach me much about statistics and I really spent most of the semester being confused and frustrated.
If the student is looking to an easy to understand and low-stress introduction to R coding and statistical analysis/inference then this is the course for them.
no. didn't really learn anything.
Unless you don't know basic math and are looking to waste a credit, I wouldn't recommend the course.

I would probably not recommend this course to another student, except maybe to a student who really needs a QR credit. I don't think this class was very conducive to actually learning and understanding statistics on a long-term basis. It was much more theory than practice, which isn't necessarily bad, but I would not say that it provided a foundation in statistics in terms of actual mathematical skills.
Not sure
Unless you just need a gut QR, then I'm not exactly sure why you would take this class.
If you are looking for a very low-level introduction to Statistic and Data Science with a minimal workload, this is a great class for you
Free QR, why not? Highkey GUT
No. Take another course if you are looking to learn statistics. This class is focused on data manipulation using R, rather than knowing the mechanics behind what you are doing.
It is an easy QR is you go to class and/or understand the textbook.
Yes, it is a great intro stats course
I would recommend this course for someone looking for an easier quantitate reasoning credit that won't require too much complex math.

I would not recommend this course to anyone who wants to gain an introductory understanding of statistics. If you are interested in learning how to code with R, this course might be more appropriate. We did very little math and focused mainly on the "big ideas" of statistics and coding. I do not feel that I came away from the class with a good understanding of basic statistics. Although, I did enjoy learning how to code with R.
Not really. It wasnt terribly engaging and while I liked the coding, the actual statistical principles were things that get covered in high school math classes.
If you want an easy QR that isn't a lot of effort, take this course.
I would recommend the next stats course.
Only if you have taken stats and are able to teach yourself the material. This is not a gut class. Take Psych Stats for the gut.

Not strongly. If you really are interested in pursuing statistics and learning to code in R, then this is probably a good starting point, but other than that, you can probably find a better course for a QR credit.
No. I dont think it teaches statistics well.
Don't take it unless you have to. Spare yourself.
I would only if they were interested in studying statistics in their future

If you are new to statistics and programming then I do recommend this course, I think it was a good introduction to both fields. However, it was not as challenging as some of the other courses I have taken.
Yes, I would recommend this class for someone looking for introductory statistics knowledge.
No, if you would like to learn statistics, you should seriously consider taking another introductory course.
I would not. I think you are better off taking a comp sci class or a math class. Didn't learn much at all from this class.
